PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Australian PM Turnbull survives leadership challenge; Earnings from Amcor and BHP
content:
AUSTRALIA

Amcor (AMC AT)
- Co. FY18 net rose 21.3% Y/Y to AUD 724mln vs. Exp. AUD 725mln, announces final dividend of AUD 0.24/Shr. (Newswires)

BHP (BHP AT)
- Co. FY18 net fell 37% Y/Y to USD 3.7bln vs. Exp. USD 6.6bln. (Newswires)
- Co. FY18 underlying profit USD 9.6bln vs. Exp. USD 9.2bln.
- Co. FY18 rev. USD 45.8bln vs. Exp. USD 45.5bln.

Healthscope (HSO AT)
- Co. FY net fell 49.9% Y/Y AUD 75.8mln. (Newswires)
- Co. announced plan for property assets spin-off.

Helloworld (HLO AT)
- Co. FY18 net rose 48.4% Y/Y to AUD 31.9mln. (Newswires)

Monadelphous Group (MND AT)
- Co. FY18 net rose 24% Y/Y to AUD 71.5mln vs. Exp. AUD 72.6mln, rev. rose 39% Y/Y to AUD 1.74bln. (Newswires)
- Co. declares final dividend of AUD 0.30/Shr.

Oil Search (OSH AT)
- Co. HY net AUD 79.2mln vs. Prev. AUD 129.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Scentre Group (SCG AT)
- Co. H1 FFO rose 3.0% Y/Y to AUD 657.2mln. (Newswires)

Senex Energy (SXY AT)
- Co. FY18 net loss AUD 94mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 22.7mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Seven West Media (SWM AT)
- Co. FY18 net AUD 135.8mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 744.3mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 1.62bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.67bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

 Super Retail Group (SUL AT)
- Co. FY net rose 26% Y/Y to AUD 128.3mln, rev. rose 4.2% Y/Y to AUD 2.57bln. (Newswires)

Wellard (WLD AT)
- Co. FY net loss AUD 36.4mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 75.3mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

WorleyParsons (WOR AT)
- Co. receives contract for construction of manufacturing facility in China. (Newswires)

Other News
- Australian PM Turnbull won leadership vote for ruling Liberal Party by 48 to 35 votes in a leadership challenge by Australian Home Affairs Minister Dutton after the leadership of the Liberal Party was declared vacant. This follows reports that PM Turnbull abandoned his energy policy and conceded he could not pass the legislation in parliament given the coalition’s 1-seat majority and opposition from within the Liberal Party led by former PM Abbott, which reports noted casted large doubts over Turnbull’s future as party leader and PM. (SMH/CNBC)  

JAPAN

Kansai Electric Power (9503 JT)
- Co. will postpone the restart of its Takahama No. 4 unit due to leak, although the Co. stated that it doesn’t expect any environmental impact from the leak. (Newswires)

Nissan Motor (7201 JT)
- Co. is said to plan JPY 100bln investment to expand China output capacity by as much as 40%. (Newswires)

Otsuka Kagu (8186 JT)
- Co. former major shareholder Brandes Investment Partners is reported to have offloaded its remaining stake in the Co. (Nikkei)

Other News
- A report notes that the BoJ is beginning to slow down the pace of ETF purchases following its decision last month to make the JPY 6tln target of its stock-buying program more flexible, which is said to have spurred speculation the central bank could be preparing to reduce the purchase amounts. (Nikkei)

SOUTH KOREA

Insurers
- South Korean life insurance firms’ total net profit rose 6.7% Y/Y during H1. (Yonhap)

Other News
- US President Trump stated that it is likely there will be a 2nd summit with North Korean leader Kim. (Newswires)
- South Korean President Moon is said to urge for an aggressive fiscal policy and has instructed aides to prepare comprehensive measures related to employment. (Newswires)

Data Recap
- South Korean PPI (Jul) M/M 0.4% (Prev. 0.0%). (Newswires)
- South Korean PPI (Jul) Y/Y 2.9% (Prev. 2.6%)

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include RBA Minutes and Governor Lowe Comments, New Zealand Credit Card Spending & Japanese 29yr Auction
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA

US President Trump said he has no time-frame for ending China trade dispute and does not anticipate much coming from the trade talks with China this week. US President Trump also accused China and Europe of currency manipulation and stated that when the US places tariffs on China, China artificially devalues its currency. (Newswires)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He stated that China are to bolster IP protection and increase legal enforcement. (Newswires)


UK/EU

EU stated their efforts are undiminished in Brexit negotiations. (Newswires)

EU Construction Output (Jun) Y/Y 2.60% vs. Exp. 1.60% (Prev. 1.80%, Rev. 2.00%). (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

DoE offered 11mln barrels sour crude for sale from the US reserves. (Newswires)

Saudi crude output rose by 459k BPD MM to 10.489mln BPD in June and Saudi crude exports rose by 260k BPD MM to 7.24mln BPD in June, according to JODI data. (Newswires)

World refined copper market deficit narrowed to 31,000 tons in May from 98,000 tons in April, according to ICSG. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said he thought he had a deal with Turkey for Pastor Brunson’s release and that he helped Israel to free a Turkish citizen for the pastor's release. US President Trump said he would consider lifting Russian sanctions if Moscow took steps to cooperate with US on issues such as Syria and Ukraine, while he also stated it is fine if Iranian President Rouhani wants to meet him but that he could not care less if not. US President Trump later added that it is likely will have a 2nd summit with North Korean leader Kim. (Newswires)
 

US

US President Trump said he disagrees with the Fed’s decision to hike interest rates and that he is not thrilled with Fed Chair Powell for doing so, while he also said Fed should be more accommodating and should give him some more help. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (voter, dovish) said the economy no longer needs the stimulus it required before and is doing pretty well with GDP strong and the unemployment rate historically very low. Bostic added the Fed is worried about flatness of yield curve, while he also stated the Fed is on a gradual path to get rates back to neutral and that he still favours 3 hikes for 2018. (Newswires)

US Agricultural Secretary Perdue said a trade war is needed to get exports up and to get a level field. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

In stock specifics, Estee Lauder (EL) reported EPS and revenue above Wall St expectations, but guided beneath expectations, and also raised its FY19 restructuring charges estimates, weighing on the stock in pre-market trade, though did go positive after the open. Tesla (TSLA) declined by as much as 8% in pre-market trade, but only opened 5% lower and losses slowly abated as trade progressed. The fall in the name was due to a negative note from JP Morgan which stated, ‘funding appears not to be secured’ and that the ‘going private’ process appears much less developed than they had earlier presumed. Also, not helping the EV maker, Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, who recently took a USD 2bln stake in TSLA, are also in discussions with one of Tesla’s rivals, Lucid Motors. Nike (NKE) outperformed, following an upgrade from Piper Jaffray & Susquehanna; the latter stated NKE is gaining market share from its competitors such as Adidas (ADS GY) and Foot Locker (FL). In M&A: PepsiCo (PEP) announced it is to acquire SodaStream (SODA) for USD 144/shr in a deal worth USD 3.2bln in cash, which represents a 10.9% premium to SODA’s closing price on Friday. Reports suggested that Apple (AAPL) is planning an updated, cheaper Mac computer to revive desktop computer sales. SPX +0.24% at 2857, NDX -0.08% at 7371, DJI +0.35% at 25758.

As US traders were getting to their desks, a slight risk-off sentiment was prevailing, and yields were edging lower. The latest CFTC data released Friday showed specs hold a record net short position in Treasuries, which prompted Doubline’s Gundlach to warn of the potential for a massive short squeeze; attention, therefore is on the general risk sentiment (Turkey is away this week following its Downgrade, for Eid; China related trade news flow seems positive, however) as well as the Fed minutes and Jackson Hole later in the week. Informa reported that buying action today was from real money accounts continuing to buy as tariffs and EM issues remain in the spotlight (though tensions have noticeably eased, broadly speaking). The front part of the curve (2s5s, 2s10s, 2s30s) narrowed, while 5s10s, 5s320s and 10s30s was more-or-less unchanged at settlement. US 10-year T-notes settled 12 ticks higher at 120-20.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 20th August 2018 - Trump takes another swipe at the Fed
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries higher, crude higher, dollar lower
  • REAR-VIEW: Trump renews criticism of the Fed; Fed’s Bostic upbeat but warns over yield curve inversion; Turkey filed WTO complaint over US tariffs; DoE offers 11mln barrels of sour crude for sale.
  • AHEAD: RBA Policy Meeting Minutes; Hungarian Interest Rate Decision Monetary; weekly APIs; GDT auction; Earnings from MDT.

* FED: US President Trump renewed his criticism of the Fed, and is said to have complained about the Fed lifting rates at a fund raising dinner. Trump reportedly lamented that Powell was not a “cheap money” Fed chair, which he expected, according to three people familiar with the matter. Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said the economy does no longer need the stimulus it required before since it is doing pretty well; GDP is 'strong' and unemployment rate is historically 'very, very low'. Bostic warned that the Fed is concerned about the flatness of the yield curve, stating that he will not knowingly vote for any policy which he believes will lead to yield curve inversion. He went on to say that it is not clear if an inverted yield curve is a signal of recession. He added the Fed is doing pretty well on its inflation objective and that it is on a gradual path to get rates back to neutral with the central aim to keep the balance sheet unwind running in the background. In terms of downside risks, he sees trade policy as the 'chief' source of uncertainty and also emphasized the Fed is watching EM such as Turley and Venezuela, following the recent turmoil. He, however, cited tax reform as an upside risk and reiterated his case for three hikes in 2018. Bostic also He also said to favour central bank independence as he believes it would allow better policy.

* TRADE:  The run of recent trade news has been constructive, with the latest NAFTA news reports Mexico’s top farm lobby said on Sunday that the US has dropped demands to impose restrictions on Mexican agricultural exports; this should enable US and Mexico to focus on the remaining outstanding issues including the auto sector rules, as the two sides come closer to a deal. It is worth noting that US President Trump does not have a mandate from Congress to negotiate a new bi-lateral trade deal with Mexico; some argue that Trump will therefore need to bring the updated deal into the NAFTA framework.  On the Canadian side, PM Trudeau said he is looking forward to more engagement shortly. The WTO confirmed on Monday that Turkey has lodged a complaint against the additional doubling up of US tariffs announced earlier in the month by the Trump administration.

* GEOPOLITICS: Turkey President Erdogan reiterated on Monday they will not ask for IMF assistance. Elsewhere, Iran again urged the EU to speed up efforts to keep Tehran in the 2015 multinational nuclear deal.

* SPX +0.24% at 2857, NDX -0.08% at 7371, DJI +0.35% at 25758. SECTORS: Energy +0.66%, Materials +0.71%, Industrials +0.64% Cons Discretionary +0.62%, Cons  Staples -0.03%, Healthcare +0.31%, Financials +0.35%, Tech -0.15%, Telecoms +0.08%, Utilities -0.35%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Estee Lauder (EL) reported EPS and revenue above Wall St expectations, but guided beneath expectations, and also raised its FY19 restructuring charges estimates, weighing on the stock in pre-market trade, though did go positive after the open. Tesla (TSLA) declined by as much as 8% in pre-market trade, but only opened 5% lower and losses slowly abated as trade progressed. The fall in the name was due to a negative note from JP Morgan which stated, ‘funding appears not to be secured’ and that the ‘going private’ process appears much less developed than they had earlier presumed. Also, not helping the EV maker, Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, who recently took a USD 2bln stake in TSLA, are also in discussions with one of Tesla’s rivals, Lucid Motors. Nike (NKE) outperformed, following an upgrade from Piper Jaffray & Susquehanna; the latter stated NKE is gaining market share from its competitors such as Adidas (ADS GY) and Foot Locker (FL). In M&A: PepsiCo (PEP) announced it is to acquire SodaStream (SODA) for USD 144/shr in a deal worth USD 3.2bln in cash, which represents a 10.9% premium to SODA’s closing price on Friday. Reports suggested that Apple (AAPL) is planning an updated, cheaper Mac computer to revive desktop computer sales.

* WTI (U8) FUTURES SETTLE  52C HIGHER AT USD 66.43/BBL, BRENT (V8) FUTURES SETTLE 38C HIGHER AT USD 72.21/BBL. Oil traded higher on Monday though the complex gave up some of the gains following a notice released by the DoE offering 11mln barrels sour crude for sale from the US reserves; it appears as though this is an inventory management measure, and was already planned. With the exception of this news, there was no real catalyst driving prices action. News flow remained relatively light after Saudi Arabia expressed willingness over the weekend to make up for any shortfall that could arise from US sanctions. On Monday the possibility of further US sanctions forced Total to exit Iran, abandoning the South Pars project which will necessitate of a replacement. Iran over the weekend warned that no OPEC member should be able to take over its share of oil exports; on Monday, it was reported that China shifted to Iranian tankers to keep oil flowing amid US sanctions. Moreover, there was confirmation that the planned strike action at three Total’s North Sea oil and gas platforms began today whilst the latest targeted missile attack by Yemeni Houthi Rebels on Saudi assets seemed to have muted impact on sentiment. Saudi reported crude output rising by 459k BPD MM to 10.489mln BPD in June and crude exports up by 260k BPD MM to 7.24mln BPD, according to JODI data. As a reminder, WTI September (U8) contract is due to expire tomorrow.

* US 10-YEAR T-NOTES SETTLED 12 TICKS HIGHER AT 120-20. As US traders were getting to their desks, a slight risk-off sentiment was prevailing, and yields were edging lower. The latest CFTC data released Friday showed specs hold a record net short position in Treasuries, which prompted Doubline’s Gundlach to warn of the potential for a massive short squeeze; attention, therefore is on the general risk sentiment (Turkey is away this week following its Downgrade, for Eid; China related trade news flow seems positive, however) as well as the Fed minutes and Jackson Hole later in the week. Informa reported that buying action today was from real money accounts continuing to buy as tariffs and EM issues remain in the spotlight (though tensions have noticeably eased, broadly speaking). The front part of the curve (2s5s, 2s10s, 2s30s) narrowed, while 5s10s, 5s320s and 10s30s was more-or-less unchanged at settlement.

* DXY: Back down towards the 96.000 handle and closer to the bottom-end of session ranges that only marginally extended to the upside from circa 96.300 to 96.400 at one stage. The general bias has been towards USD weakness as we approach APAC trade, with traders citing US/China trade talk hopes (helping CNH to gain, lifting some of its Asian counterparts) as well as reduced EM angst in Turkey (which is on holiday for Eid this week).

* GBP: The outlier and perhaps unexpected outperformer amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty and more EU warnings that the UK could conceivably leave without any deal. However, Cable made a more concerted run at 1.2750 and took out stops through to a circa 1.2775 high, while EURGBP slipped back towards 0.8950.

* CHF, JPY: Also firmer vs the Dollar amidst another bout of weakness in EMs (SA Rand aside due to short covering/consolidation after recent steep ZAR depreciation), as the Franc retreated from 0.9970 to 0.9935 and 1.1350 vs almost 1.1400 vs the Eur, while USDJPY took another look at bids/support at 110.50, but not quite stops said to be placed on a break of 110.30.

* CAD, EUR, AUD, NZD: The Loonie weakened alongside crude prices from best levels around 1.3055 vs its US counterpart to 1.3090 or thereabout, but recovered some poise as BoC’s Wilkins stated that mortgage borrowers will see a rise in financing costs at some stage. So, no explicit mention about higher policy rates, but market expectations for tightening as early as September have climbed over 40% after last Friday’s much stronger than forecast headline Canadian inflation data. The single currency survived a brief dip below 1.1400 vs the USD that appeared to coincide with a chase down to 126.00 in EURJPY, but is back near its 200 HMA at 1.1438, while the AUD remains above 0.7300 vs the Greenback, albeit tentatively and facing the prospect of more dovish policy guidance from RBA Governor Lowe tonight. Nevertheless, the NZD has been the laggard all day with the Kiwi hovering between 0.6640-10 and mostly nearer the bottom end, as the AUDNZD cross firmed back up above 1.1000 within a 1.1020-50 range.

* TRY: The Lira succumbed to more investor angst after S&P’s ratings cut and with no support from FX depo or repo auctions, while the latest tirade against speculators and the US attacking the country from Turkish President Erdogan largely fell on deaf ears. Indeed, USDTRY rebounded even more firmly from sub-6.0000 lows to just shy of 6.2000 as the stalemate over US Pastor Brunson and sanctions rumbled on.

* AHEAD: All in all, an inauspicious start to a week that really kicks off in earnest later via ECB and Fed minutes, Jackson Hole and the US-China trade talks that may be labelled as ‘low’ level, but apparently have been prefaced by a roadmap to resolve the reciprocal import tariff tiff by November. USDCNH currently around 6.8580 after a lower USDCNY fix by the PBoC overnight (at 6.8718 from 6.8894 last Friday).

subject: The DoE has offered 11mln barrels sour crude for sale from the US reserves, newswires report
content:
• The U.S. Department of Energy’s (DOE) Office of Fossil Energy (FE) announced today a Notice of Salefor crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR).
  • Under Section 5010 of the 21st Century Cures Act, the Secretary of Energy is directed to draw down and sell a total of 25 million barrels of crude oil from the SPR, over 3 consecutive fiscal years (FY), beginning in FY 2017.  Of this amount, DOE is selling 6 million barrels in FY 2019.  Under Section 403 of the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, the Secretary of Energy is directed to draw down and sell a total of 58 million barrels of crude oil from the SPR, over 8 consecutive FYs, commencing in FY 2018. Of this amount, DOE is selling 5 million barrels in FY 2019. 
  • FE plans to draw down and sell a total of 11 million barrels of crude oil from the SPR.  Crude oil will be sold from three sites—Bryan Mound and Big Hill in Texas, and West Hackberry in Louisiana.  This sale will fulfill requirements for Section 5010(a)(1)(C) of the 21st Century Cures Act (Public Law 114-255) and Section 403(a)(2) of the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015 (Public Law 114-74).  
  • Via Department of Energy
reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction WTI futures fell from USD 66.42 to USD 66.08

Fixed and FX latest: Bunds and Gilts revisit/set new session highs, Usd drifts
content: Having diverged completely for much of the session, core EU bonds and USTs moved more in lock-step recently as the 10 year core debt futures rebounded further from worst levels to retest 123.72 highs in Bunds and strike a marginal new Liffe peak at 123.78 for Gilts (+3 ticks vs -21 ticks at the other extreme). This as US Treasuries recover well amidst block sales (decent 5k clips in 5 and 10 year tenors) and amidst very heavy buying at the short end of the US curve (100k lots bought in Dec18 Eurodollars at 97.395, and the 3 month contract subsequently up to 97.410). Turning to FX, choppy, August, seasonal trade continues with the DXY back towards lows between 96.400-010 and G10 pairs whippy, mixed , but still essentially rangebound.

20th August 2018

Earnings

  • Estee Lauder (EL) Q4 EPS USD 0.61 vs Exp. USD 0.56, Revenue USD 3.3bln vs Exp. USD 3.25bln. Sees Q1 Adj. EPS USD 1.18-1.22, consensus USD 1.32. Sees FY19 Adj. EPS USD 4.62-4.71 (consensus USD 4.99). Raises FY19 restructuring charges to USD 900mln-950mln from USD 600mln-700mln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant removed 25,000 of apps from China’s app store after it was labelled illegal since they failed to comply with local regulations. (AI)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – Mutual funds operated by the bank are facing paper losses of at least USD 63mln on purchases of USD 865mln of bonds made from Venezuela made last year. (WSJ)  
  • Walmart (WMT) – Anthem (ANTM) announces a collaboration with the Walmart, which will enable Anthem affiliates enrolled in Medicare Advantage plans to use OTC plan allowances to buy over the counter medications. Separately, Walmart. announced the completion of its investment in Flipkart, becoming the co.’s biggest shareholder. Separately, it has asked beauty suppliers to source products from outside China as a way to lessen the impacts of US tariffs on China products. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Air Products (APD) – The co. was awarded a contract to build and run a coal-to-syngas plant in China. (Newswires)
  • Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) – The FDA has accepted the Priority Review of ALXN1210 for the treatment of paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria. (Newswires)
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) – The oil group has signed a USD 2bln settlement with PDVSA, to be paid over a four and a half year period. As part of the settlement, ConocoPhillips agrees to suspend legal enforcement actions of the ICC award. (Newswires)
  • Hess Corp (HES) - The US oil producer's Southeast Asian offshore natural gas assets, estimated value of USD 5bln, are attracting takeover attempts from firms including Thailand's PTTEP and Austrian energy group OMV. (Newswires)
  • PepsiCo (PEP) – The soft drinks producer agrees to acquire SodaStream (SODA) for USD 144/shr in a deal totalling USD 3.2bln in cash, an 10.9% premium to Friday’s closing price. (Newswires)
  • Praxair (PX) - The European Commission is set to announce its decision on the co.’s merger with Linde (LIN GY) today. (Newswires)
  • Tyson Foods (TSN) – The co. confirmed to acquire Keystone Foods from Brazil Marfrig Global Foods for USD 2.1bln. On Friday it was reported the two agreed to a deal. (Newswires)
  • Vertex (VRTX) – The co. has received a positive recommendation from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) for Orkambi in Australia for the treatment of cystic fibrosis in patients aged 6+. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s negative on Walmart (WMT). State Street (STT), Verizon (VZ). Barron’s positive on BrightView (BV), AbbVie (ABBV), LyondellBasell (LYB), Broadcom (AVGO), Regions Financial (RF), Starbucks (SBUX), CF Industries (CF), Mosaic (MOS), Nutrien (NTR), Kohl (KSS).

NASDAQ 100

  • Facebook (FB) – The US government is looking to force the social network to break the encryption in Messenger to access conversations as part of a criminal investigation. Separately, the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) submitted a complaint against the social media stating it violates a law by allowing landlords and home sellers to use its advertising platform to engage in housing discrimination; Facebook responded stating discrimination is strictly prohibited in its policy and it is working with the HUD to address those concerns. (Newswires)
  • FANG (FB, AMZN, NFLX, GOOGL) – A selloff in Chinese internet stocks and the recent weakness in the FANG group has caused worries among some investors, according to Reuters. (Reuters)
  • Netflix (NFLX) – The movie platform is testing ads for original content that will be streamed in between TV episodes. (Business Insider)
  • Social networks (FB, TWTR, GOOGL) – The EU is to intervene on social media platforms if content flagged as terrorist material in not removed within one hour. Separately, US President Trump tweeted over the weekend ‘Social Media is totally discriminating against Republican/Conservative voices. Speaking loudly and clearly for the Trump Administration, we won’t let that happen. They are closing down the opinions of many people on the RIGHT, while at the same time doing nothing to others.......’ (FT/Twitter)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – JP Morgan cuts its price target for the automaker to USD 195 from USD 308, saying ‘funding appears not to be secured’ and that the ‘going private’ process appears much less developed than they had earlier presumed. In other news, Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund is in discussions to invest in Tesla rival Lucid Motors; previously Saudi Arabia said it could help CEO Elon Musk in his plan to take the co. private. Elsewhere, CEO Elon Musk said in response to a tweet calling for a healthier lifestyle that cutting working hours is not an option. (JP Morgan/Newswires/CNBC)
  • T-Mobile (TMUS) - The US telecom co. is asking smaller wireless networks that use its network to release public statements in approval of the co.'s takeover bid of competitor Sprint Corp (S). The takeover bid is currently under review by the FCC and DOJ. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Bilibili (BILI) – The co. and Aniplex announced an extension of their operation agreement for FGO in mainland China. (Newswires)
  • GasLog (GLOG) – The co. signed two charter party agreements with Cheniere Energy (LNG) subsidiary. (Newswires)
  • Live Nation (LYV) – CFO sells 40k shares in the co. (Newswires)

  • Tronox (TROX) – The European Commission issued final approval for the co.’s proposed acquisition of a privately held crystal co, in Jessah, Saudi Arabia. (Newswires)
  • Westlake Chemical (WLK) – The co. raises quarterly dividend by 19% to USD 0.25/shr and boosts share repurchase programme by USD 150mln. (Newswires)
  • China Biologic (CBPO) – A consortium of investors including: David Gao, GL Capital Group, Bank of China Group Investment Limited, and CDH Investments have made a non-binding proposal to acquire CBPO at USD 118/shr for a total value of approx. USD 3.9bln. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 20th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities accelerated gains (Eurostoxx 50 +0.8%) as sentiment improved across the region amid Friday’s US-China trade developments
  • TRY is back under pressure after S&P’s downgrade and no FX Depo auction today, with comments from President Erdogan largely shrugged off
  • Looking ahead, highlights include speeches by Fed’s Bostic and ECB’s Weidmann

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains contained as the region struggled for direction due to a lack of fresh catalysts and as earnings dominated news flow. ASX 200 (+0.1%) traded positive but with price action kept in a tight range as strength in miners was counterbalanced by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector and consumer staples following disappointing results from Woolworths, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) underperformed amid a firmer currency and as some analysts even suggested stealth tapering after the BoJ refrained from buying stocks for 2 days last week. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) traded higher but with sentiment in the mainland bourse flimsy as it swung from gains and losses, however the bulls eventually took the upper hand following another firm liquidity effort by the PBoC and continued hopes regarding trade talks. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially uneventful amid a similar tone across asset classes and a lack of BoJ presence in the bond market, although prices gradually edged higher throughout the session amid the underperformance of stocks in Tokyo which helped 10yr JGBs break above resistance around the 150.50 level.

PBoC injected CNY 120bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8718 (Prev. 6.8894)

US

US Trade Representative Lighthizer will hold a hearing on China tariffs in August, while it was also reported on Friday that US and China trade talks have a plotted road map to resolve trade dispute by November. (Newswires/WSJ)

Fitch affirmed Russia at 'BBB-; Outlook Positive. (Newswires)

TURKEY

US reportedly reject Turkey’s offer of releasing Pastor Brunson in exchange for bank relief. (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan reiterated Turkey will not ask for IMF assistance. (Anadolu Agency)

S&P downgraded Turkey from BB- to B+; Outlook Stable and Moody’s also cut Turkey from Ba2 to Ba3; Outlook Negative

UK

UK government is to publish no-deal advice on Thursday, notices will include advice for businesses, citizens and public bodies. Thursday will also see UK Brexit Secretary Raab making a speech in Westminster to outline plans in the case of a no-deal Brexit. (BBC)

UK Cabinet papers showed plans for EU migrants to be given the right to stay in UK in the event of a no-deal amid worries of potential labour shortages. (Telegraph)

UK Tory Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg warned PM May that Eurosceptics will block her plans unless they are changed, while the group are also reported to be devising an alternative proposal to PM May’s Brexit plans. (Independent)

EU

ECB’s Weidmann (Hawk) stated that monetary policy normalization is foreseeable following the latest decisions and that interest rates will increase as a result, although the process will be gradual. (Newswires)

Italy’s populist government are drawing up a plan of up to EUR 80bln to rebuild the country’s rundown infrastructure after the Genoa bridge collapse. Italy's Deputy PM Salvini said all funds raised for infrastructure will be invested. (Telegraph/Newswires)

The Italian cabinet undersecretary Giorgetti has indicated he wanted the ECB to continue buying fresh bonds, including Italian government debt, under its QE programme. (FT)

German Finance Ministry noted that TRY crisis, US tariffs and Brexit are risks to the German economy. (Newswires)

ESM stated that Greece successfully completed its bailout programme. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Iran says the EU should speed up efforts to keep Tehran in the 2015 multinational nuclear deal. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities kick started the week higher by 0.2% to 0.3% before gains accelerated (Eurostoxx 50 +0.8%) as sentiment improved across the region amid the latest US-China trade developments. On Friday, it was reported US and China have a plotted road map to resolve trade disputes by November. In terms of sectors, material names are outperforming on the back of firmer base metals price actions. Antofagasta (+2.2%) shares are higher after also reporting optimistic numbers while reaffirming CapEx guidance. Elsewhere, Atlantia (-9.0%) shares continue take a beating, the latest reports suggesting the Italian government has begun revoking Autostrade’s licence, also casting doubt over an initial offer of EUR 500mln for compensation and building work from Atlantia.

FX

USD - The broad Dollar and DXY is mildly firmer, but well within established ranges and G10 pairs are narrowly mixed even though risk appetite suggests that a degree of divergence between traditional safe-havens and high beta currencies would better reflect the overall tone.  Hence, the index is relatively lacklustre within 96.300-010 bounds awaiting firmer direction and impulses that could arrive later this week via US-China trade talks, FOMC minutes and/or Jackson Hole.

NZD/EUR/JPY - Highlighting the rather indifferent and conflicting start to the week, the Kiwi, single currency and Jpy are all underperforming at the base of the major pecking order, with the former just about retaining 0.6600+ status, Eur/Usd still struggling to extend rebounds above 1.1400 (topping out ahead of the 200 HMA at 1.1458) and Usd/Jpy continuing to pivot around 110.50 (albeit Eur/Jpy also capped circa 126.50 and under its 200 HMA of 126.82).

CAD/AUD/GBP/CHF - Essentially flat-lining vs the Greenback, but with the Loonie holding near recent highs circa 1.3055 after last Friday’s BoC rate hike boosting Canadian CPI data and eyeing a speech from Governor Wilkins this afternoon, while the Aud straddles 0.7300 again wary of more unsupportive RBA rhetoric in the form of dovish guidance from Governor Lowe who is due to speak later tonight. Elsewhere, Cable is also aimless around a 1.2750 axis awaiting further Brexit developments and the Franc is even more restrained either side of 0.9950.

EM - The Try is back under pressure after S&P’s downgrade and no FX Depo auction today, with comments from President Erdogan largely shrugged off or arguably undermining the Lira if anything, although the US rejecting Turkey’s offer to release Pastor Brunson in exchange for bank aid is probably more of a negative factor. Usd/Try back near 6.1000, in contrast to Usd/Rub around 67.0000 in wke of Fitch affirming Russia and Usd/Zar sub-14.5000 in consolidation after last week’s Rand slump and ahead of SA inflation data and the beginning of testimonies for the capture inquest.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts have pared some losses after extending intraday lows to 163.42 and 123.54 on Eurex and Liffe respectively (-1/4 point and -21 ticks on the day), as EU stocks climb higher, Italian BTPs get a boost from comments by Salvini claiming that infrastructure funding is in place, and perhaps less intuitively a relatively firm rebound in US Treasuries. Nothing concrete to support the suggestion, but it would certainly be reasonable and feasible to deduce that the 10 year EU benchmarks have conceded ground to any or all of the above, ie via asset reallocation and/or spread positioning.

COMMODITIES

WTI (Unch) and Brent (+0.4%) trade mixed, with the former eyeing USD 66/bbl to the upside while the latter straddling above USD 72.00/bbl. News flow for crude was light over the weekend, although Iran expressed opposition to Saudi Arabia’s willingness to make up for any shortfall that could arise from US sanctions, in which it told OPEC that no country is allowed to take over the share of other members for production and exports of oil under any circumstances.

Elsewhere, gold (+0.3%) is in the green as it crawls closer to the USD 1190/oz level. London copper rose 1% this morning as hopes for US-Sino trade talks buoyed risk appetite after reports suggested China and Washington are to hold low-level trade talks on August 21st and 22nd, ahead of the new US tariffs on USD 16bln of Chinese goods take effect.

UK union confirmed the offshore oil & gas platform strike has begun at the three platforms Alwyn, Elgin and Dunbar. (Newswires)

China are said to have shifted to Iranian tankers to keep oil flowing amid US sanctions. (Newswires)

subject: France has objected to plans for a Brexit hard shipping corridor, according to Le Monde
content:
• Le Monde reports This regards a proposal to adjust the route of the maritime corridor between Ireland and the UK in a hard Brexit scenario between London and Brussels on March 30th. 

  • France see the proposal as "unacceptable" because the proposed new link should favor the Dutch and Belgian ports, to the detriment of French ports.

  • via Le Monde

subject: Petrobras says a fire occurred at its Replan refinery in Sao Paulo, no injuries reported. Petrobras says the fire is under control and they paralyzed production preemptively
analysis_details:
• Replan is Petrobars' largest refinery in throughput: 66.000 cubic meters per day, equivalent to 415K BPD.
  • Its production corresponds to 20% of all of the oil refining in Brazil, processing approximately 80% of the domestic oil,

content: • The report states private consumption in Germany wold continue to drive growth and should benefit from a strong labour market and strong wage increases, thus retaining its role as a key pillar of growth

subject: Fixed Income: a bit more switching out of core EU debt
content: Bunds and Gilts have pared some losses after extending intraday lows to 163.42 and 123.54 on Eurex and Liffe respectively (-1/4 point and -21 ticks on the day), as EU stocks climb higher, Italian BTPs get a boost from comments by Salvini claiming that infrastructure funding is in place, and perhaps less intuitively a relatively firm rebound in US Treasuries. Nothing concrete to support the suggestion, but it would certainly be reasonable and feasible to deduce that the 10 year EU benchmarks have conceded ground to any or all of the above, ie via asset reallocation and/or spread positioning.

subject: FX Morning Colour: risk sentiment somewhat mixed, and currencies muddled
content:
USD

The broad Dollar and DXY is mildly firmer, but well within established ranges and G10 pairs are narrowly mixed even though risk appetite suggests that a degree of divergence between traditional safe-havens and high beta currencies would better reflect the overall tone.  Hence, the index is relatively lacklustre within 96.300-010 bounds awaiting firmer direction and impulses that could arrive later this week via US-China trade talks, FOMC minutes and/or Jackson Hole.

NZD/EUR/JPY

Highlighting the rather indifferent and conflicting start to the week, the Kiwi, single currency and Jpy are all underperforming at the base of the major pecking order, with the former just about retaining 0.6600+ status, Eur/Usd still struggling to extend rebounds above 1.1400 (topping out ahead of the 200 HMA at 1.1458) and Usd/Jpy continuing to pivot around 110.50 (albeit Eur/Jpy also capped circa 126.50 and under its 200 HMA of 126.82).

CAD/AUD/GBP/CHF

Essentially flat-lining vs the Greenback, but with the Loonie holding near recent highs circa 1.3055 after last Friday’s BoC rate hike boosting Canadian CPI data and eyeing a speech from Governor Wilkins this afternoon, while the Aud straddles 0.7300 again wary of more unsupportive RBA rhetoric in the form of dovish guidance from Governor Lowe who is due to speak later tonight. Elsewhere, Cable is also aimless around a 1.2750 axis awaiting further Brexit developments and the Franc is even more restrained either side of 0.9950.

EM

The Try is back under pressure after S&P’s downgrade and no FX Depo auction today, with comments from President Erdogan largely shrugged off or arguably undermining the Lira if anything, although the US rejecting Turkey’s offer to release Pastor Brunson in exchange for bank aid is probably more of a negative factor. Usd/Try back near 6.1000, in contrast to Usd/Rub around 67.0000 in wke of Fitch affirming Russia and Usd/Zar sub-14.5000 in consolidation after last week’s Rand slump and ahead of SA inflation data and the beginning of testimonies for the capture inquest.

Morgan Stanley Cross-Asset Playbook: Equal weight Equities & Rates, Underweight Credit, Overweight Cash
content:
Key views and trades:

  • We like buying vol in US small caps, long JPY, long UST 2s10s flattener and long CDX HY puts as good DM hedges for a potential EM spillover. We reduce risk further by closing out long South Africa bonds, and putting on a long Topix 3m put. We also close long European 2y2y HICP swap on relative lack of upside.
  • In equities, Europe remains our most preferred region, EM and Japan are least preferred.
  • In rates, we prefer US Treasuries and EM local rates over Bunds and JGBs.
  • In credit, we prefer EM sovereign credit to DM credit, and have a preference for EU over US within DM credit.

Similarly, the Short Sterling strip has been mostly flat to 1 ticks adrift in contrast to a mild bid in Eurodollar contracts beyond front month Sep18, and for no real obvious reason. subject: Bunds: inauspicious start to the new week
content: Very little deviation from parity in early Eurex trade, but the 10 year German benchmark is trying to inch up from a 163.61 low having opened just two ticks below last Friday’s 163.67 close and reached 163.72 before fading. Flatter/firmer trade is more in keeping with the tone in US Treasuries ahead of a potentially pivotal week on the US-China trade front and in terms of CB commentary via ECB and Fed minutes, plus anything more up to date emerging from Jackson Hole. More immediately, the resumption of EU cash equities may provide some direction before the Bundesbank monthly bulletin, weekly ECB QE tallies and a speech from Weidmann after hours.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS** 

20th August 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains contained as the region struggled for direction due to a lack of fresh catalysts and as earnings dominated news flow. ASX 200 (+0.1%) traded positive but with price action kept in a tight range as strength in miners was counterbalanced by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector and consumer staples following disappointing results from Woolworths, while Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) underperformed amid a firmer currency and as some analysts even suggested stealth tapering after the BoJ refrained from buying stocks for 2 days last week. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) traded higher but with sentiment in the mainland bourse flimsy as it swung from gains and losses, however the bulls eventually took the upper hand following another firm liquidity effort by the PBoC and continued hopes regarding trade talks. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially uneventful amid a similar tone across asset classes and a lack of BoJ presence in the bond market, although prices gradually edged higher throughout the session amid the underperformance of stocks in Tokyo which helped 10yr JGBs break above resistance around the 150.50 level.

FTSE

UK-Based Banking Names – Standard Chartered boss Clarke has warned that the EU may force banking jobs out of the UK post-Brexit. (Guardian)

Energy Names – Household are expected to pay GBP 60 or more as energy suppliers are expected to pass-on the higher costs of  an energy tariff increase to consumers. (Guardian)

Sainsbury (SBRY LN) – The merger with Asda may force the sale of up to 300 shops, as a result of competition concerns. (Times)

BT (BT/A LN) – Some of BT largest shareholders have called on the new CEO of the co. to consider a break-up of the co. so as to create value. (FT)

Prudential (PRU LN) – The Chairman of Just Eat, Evans, is being lined-up for the Chairman role of M&G Prudential prior to its demerger from parent co. Prudential in 2020, as according to sources. Elsewhere, Co. is to consolidate non-UK European insurance in Ireland as part of their Brexit planning. (Sky/Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

G4S (GFS LN) – The MoJ has taken over running a Birmingham prison after it decided that G4S had “slipped into crisis”, after it discovered violence and uncleanliness. (Sky)

Micro Focus (MCRO LN) - Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) have disclosed a 5.01% stake in Micro Focus (MCRO LN).

Esure (ESUR LN) – CEO Wood has signed an agreement to sell the business for GBP 1.2bln to Bain Capital, with two new CEO candidates reportedly shortlisted. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

BMW (BMW GY) – The co. will reportedly give the raising of its stake in their Chinese JV careful consideration, as according to a co. executive. (Xinhua)

Daimler (DAI GY) – The co. has been threatened with the recall of 100’s of thousands of 24 models as a result of emissions manipulation concerns by Germany’s KBA. (Der Spiegel)

Linde (LIN GY) – The European Commission will announce its decision on the co.’s merger with Praxair (PX) today. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – The co.’s CEO Diess was reportedly told about the existence of cheating software in cars two months prior to regulators discovered the emissions scandal. Elsewhere, the co. is to give a 5.5% wage increase in Mexico and another raise next year, as according to a Mexican union leader. (Der Spiegel)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The bank is said to have offered to buy the bonds of Noble Group (CGP SG).(Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

WireCard (WDI GY) – Chinese said to be in talks with the co. to acquire a 25% stake, may make a move for the whole company. (Betaville)

BROKER MOVES

BAYER (BAYN GY) RESUMED WITH OUTPERFROM AT CREDIT SUISSE

CAC

Euronext (ENX FP) – The Co. is said to have offered over USD 1bln for the US Co. IHS Markit (INFO). (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

SCANDINAVIA

Volvo (VOLVB SS) – The CEO of the Co. has called for the removal of auto tariffs, saying the removal would provide consumers with “more choice, better cars and more value for money” (FT).

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – China National Drug Administration grants rapid approval of Co.’s Alecensa (alectinib) as a treatment for ALK-positive lung cancer. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

Despite the co.’s CEO saying that he will not resign, reports have suggested that a resignation may be offered to smooth out relations with the government. (FT/Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 20th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains contained as the region struggled for direction due to a lack of fresh catalysts and as earnings dominated news flow
  • FX markets were relatively uneventful amid a lack of data releases or macro drivers, EUR/USD and GBP/USD stall around the 1.1450 and 1.2750 levels respectively
  • Looking ahead, highlights include a speech by Fed’s Bostic on the economic outlook

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains contained as the region struggled for direction due to a lack of fresh catalysts and as earnings dominated news flow. ASX 200 (+0.1%) traded positive but with price action kept in a tight range as strength in miners was counterbalanced by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector and consumer staples following disappointing results from Woolworths, while Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) underperformed amid a firmer currency and as some analysts even suggested stealth tapering after the BoJ refrained from buying stocks for 2 days last week. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) traded higher but with sentiment in the mainland bourse flimsy as it swung from gains and losses, however the bulls eventually took the upper hand following another firm liquidity effort by the PBoC and continued hopes regarding trade talks. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially uneventful amid a similar tone across asset classes and a lack of BoJ presence in the bond market, although prices gradually edged higher throughout the session amid the underperformance of stocks in Tokyo which helped 10yr JGBs break above resistance around the 150.50 level.

PBoC injected CNY 120bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8718 (Prev. 6.8894)


UK

UK government is to publish no-deal advice on Thursday, notices will include advice for businesses, citizens and public bodies. Thursday will also see UK Brexit Secretary Raab making a speech in Westminster to outline plans in the case of a no-deal Brexit. (BBC)

UK Cabinet papers showed plans for EU migrants to be given the right to stay in UK in the event of a no-deal amid worries of potential labour shortages. (Telegraph)

Ministers are facing calls to focus on UK’s trade with the EU as they look for new markets ahead of Brexit. This comes as UK Trade Secretary Fox’s international trade department prepares to set out support for companies in its export strategy. (Times)

UK Tory Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg warned PM May that Eurosceptics will block her plans unless they are changed, while the group are also reported to be devising an alternative proposal to PM May’s Brexit plans. (Independent)

The monthly Institute of Directors (IoD) tracker found business leaders' confidence in the UK economy has fallen to its lowest point this year amid a potential chaotic Brexit. (Telegraph)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Aug) M/M -2.30% (Prev. -0.10%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Aug) Y/Y 1.10% (Prev. 1.40%)


EU

ECB’s Weidmann (Hawk) stated that monetary policy normalization is foreseeable following the latest decisions and that interest rates will increase as a result, although the process will be gradual. (Newswires)

Italy’s populist government are drawing up a plan of up to EUR 80bln to rebuild the country’s rundown infrastructure after the Genoa bridge collapse. (Telegraph)

The Italian cabinet undersecretary Giorgetti has indicated he wanted the ECB to continue buying fresh bonds, including Italian government debt, under its QE programme. (FT)

German Finance Ministry noted that TRY crisis, US tariffs and Brexit are risks to the German economy. (Newswires)

ESM stated that Greece successfully completed its bailout programme. (Newswires)

S&P downgraded Turkey from BB- to B+; Outlook Stable and Moody’s also cut Turkey from Ba2 to Ba3; Outlook Negative, while Fitch affirmed Russia at 'BBB-'; Outlook Positive. (Newswires)
 

FX

FX markets were relatively uneventful amid a lack of data releases or macro drivers. Nonetheless, the greenback attempted to recover some of Friday’s losses against its major counterparts which saw EUR/USD and GBP/USD stall around the 1.1450 and 1.2750 levels respectively, while a mild pullback was also seen in AUD/USD and NZD/USD in which the former just about held onto the 0.7300 handle. Elsewhere, JPY marginally benefitted from cross-related flows and CNY gained against USD to strengthen past 6.8500 after the PBoC set a firmer reference rate.


COMMODITIES

Commodities mirrored the uneventful picture across asset classes in which WTI crude futures marginally weakened and declined below USD 65.00/bbl for the October contract. Pertinent news flow for crude was light over the weekend although Iran had expressed opposition to Saudi Arabia’s willingness to make up for any shortfall that could arise from US sanctions, in which it told OPEC that no country is allowed to take over the share of other members for production and exports of oil under any circumstances. Elsewhere, gold was relatively flat with prices subdued as the greenback attempted to nurse losses, while copper was marginally higher amid the mostly positive risk tone.

Baker Hughes Rig Count Total Rigs unchanged at 1057. (Newswires)

Iran told OPEC that members should not be permitted to take over another member's share of oil exports, after Saudi Arabia had offered to increase output to cover any Iranian shortfall. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US reportedly reject Turkey’s offer of releasing Pastor Brunson in exchange for bank relief. (Newswires)


US

Slight flattening of the curve was seen on Friday by settlement, and yields are ultimately little changed. There was little move after a miss on the University of Michigan sentiment data, and Treasuries edged higher. The complex was positive up until a news report suggesting that the US and Chinese were working on a roadmap to reach a resolution in their trade dispute by November. The headline saw a move into risk, to the detriment of Treasuries. US 10-year T-notes settled half-a-tick tick lower at 120-08.

US Trade Representative Lighthizer will hold a hearing on China tariffs in August, while it was also reported on Friday that US and China trade talks have a plotted road map to resolve trade dispute by November. (Newswires/WSJ)

US and Mexico narrowed differences on farm trade in NAFTA talks, while there were also reports the US dropped the agriculture demand from NAFTA talks, according to Mexico’s top farm lobby. In related news, White House advisor Hassett commented that they are very close to reaching a trade deal with Mexico, while Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo stated that they are hoping to conclude the remaining bilateral issues with the US by the middle of this week including auto rules of origin. (Newswires)
